Configure Duck DNS

Duck DNS is a free dynamic DNS service that allows 5 free domains under duckdns.org.

  • Go to Duck DNS official web site and create a free account. You will be assigned a token <DUCK_DNS_TOKEN>.
  • Add a domain by writing your <DOMAIN_NAME> and clicking add domain. Domain will be http://<DOMAIN_NAME>.duckdns.org.
  • Write your router's public IP address and click update ip. You can get it by googling what is my ip.

Auto update IP address

If your router does not have a static public IP, it will probably change at some point. In order to keep Duck DNS up to date, you can write a script that will be running from an always on device inside your home network. Below is an example of systemd service script.

  • Create a file /etc/systemd/user/duckdns.service with the following content:
[Unit]
Description=Updates DuckDNS entry with correct IP address

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=curl -sS "https://www.duckdns.org/update/<DOMAIN_NAME>/<DUCK_DNS_TOKEN>"

Create another file /etc/systemd/user/duckdns.timer with the following content:

[Unit]
Description=Run duckdns.service every 60 seconds

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*-*-* *:*:00
Unit=duckdns.service

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

To enable both unit files and reload systemd daemon, run the following commands:

sudo systemctl enable duckdns.service
sudo systemctl enable duckdns.timer
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl restart duckdns.timer
